One Week In October...20 Young Breast Cancer Survivors Check out their web site (click the title listed above, otherwise: urlLink http://www.changinggears.org/ ) This is so damn exciting! My first out-of-state motorcycle adventure. ## "Changing Gears" will take place from October 2 - 9, 2004 in Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and will gain added media interest due to its unique nature, novelty and timing. From October 2 - 9, 2004 twenty young breast cancer survivors will embark on the adventure of a lifetime, riding motorcycles down the coast of California from San Francisco to San Diego. Sundance Festival Award Winning Documentary Maker, Melissa Regan, has joined the project to make a film of the ride. "Changing Gears" is a unique high profile advocacy, community building and fundraising event created for and by young women living with breast cancer. Over the course of a week, they will raise awareness of the unique needs of young women living with breast cancer, challenge media stereotypes, raise funds for breast cancer causes and continue along their own personal path of growth and healing by building a supportive community with their fellow survivors. It's the adventure of a lifetime! Motorcycles, riding gear and riding lessons will be provided to all participants thanks to our generous sponsors. ## Of course, I know how to ride and have the gear, so I'll be using their bikes. This is probably going to be the MOST exciting trip I've taken to date. Watch for massive picture updates after I get back mid-October. What's so exciting, is that I'm going to meet other women riders that are YOUNG and BC survivors. How cool is that!

urlLink Google Search: dairy queen near Soldotna, AK 99669 So I had a sad ride yesterday. I felt like crap all morning, not even being able to finish my 16 oz Saturday Breve. I was sweaty and clammy feeling the whole morning. I kept telling Jon that I wished I felt better. I met two ladies at Totem parking lot, then drove down to urlLink Potter Valley Train Station. . The ride felt good, because I didn't feel so sweaty. We rode down to Girdwood Bakery and got donuts and some of the ladies got coffee. I saw a few other lady riders that I knew, said hello and continued to hope I'd feel better. We left at 11:30 from Girdwood, heading to Soldotna. I made it to the Dairy Queen but was so ill feeling that I didn't even get to have a Peanut Buster Parfait! I actually left the ladies to themselves and came back to Anchorage (147 miles away!). I made it home in 2.5 hours, although I wished I would have turned around in Girdwood. I sure was glad to have pulled into my garage; I was freezing from cold sweats and hot flashes, so ended up using every last bit of hot water in our house, hopped into bed, slept a few hours, then the "fun" started. I ended up with the stomach flu - vomiting twice. I'm feeling very hazing today - like yesterday didn't happen. I can't believe I traveled over 300 miles that sick. I'm sad to have missed out on the overnight run. I think Jon & I are going to do the overnighter with ourselves in a couple of weekends - possibly Gakona for a LONG overnight ride. WOO-HOO!

My mother-in-law, urlLink Susan Lang , does not have lung cancer or lymphoma, as the MDs had thought. After several tests, lots of chest x-rays/CTs, etc., and multiple pokes in the back to remove excess lung fluid as well as biopsy of a lymph node, they don't know what the hell it is, but it shows NO signs of cancer. It maybe some sort of virus, but again, they really don't know. They'll consult with the lung specialist and surgeon in a few weeks to try figuring it out. The good news it isn't cancer. On a sad note, a dear friend's husband was diagnosed with lung cancer yesterday. There is a possibly that it is inoperable. He had the same sorts of symptoms as Sue had, but his is exactly what we were all hoping it wasn't. This is terrible - he hasn't smoked a pipe in 1.5 years and hasn't smoke cigarettes in 30 years. I'm kind of at a loss regarding what to do to support them. I thought I'd be better at this, especially since I'm a breast cancer survivor, but I'm just shocked and at a loss about what to do for them. I feel helpless on this end and they probably feel helpless on their end. On top of all this, my Dad continues to smoke cigars - which are just as bad, if not worse, than cigarettes. It makes me sick!

Each day the details are getting more exciting! An Amazon Heart Event Photojournalist Joins Our Ride! We are delighted to welcome Photojournalist Jill Karnicki to Changing Gears! Jill will accompany us up the coast of California, documenting the ride as part of a breast cancer project she is engaged in. Jill Karnicki is a graduate student in Visual Communications at Ohio University. She chose to return to school after working for seven years as a staff photographer and photo editor at two Los Angeles Times community newspapers in Glendale and Burbank, CA. During her time there, she began her interest in breast cancer issues, participating in fund-raising walks and telling the stories of women affected by breast cancer in her community. Breast cancer became much more than a newspaper story to her when she lost her best friend, Michelle Rothwell, to the disease in May of 2003. She was 31 years old. In her honor, and with the hope of helping other young women become aware that breast cancer can affect you at any age, Jill has decided to create an educational CD rom about the realities of breast cancer and young women as her masters project. It will focus on several, diverse women's stories and the issues they face. It will also have medical and support resources, including Amazon Heart, Young Survival Coalition, and Y-ME. She will include stories and photographs from Changing Gears as an ending to her CD rom. She feels it will be a positive, inspiring way to spread the message of living each day to it's fullest. Welcome aboard Jill! Megan and Meredith 2004 Amazon Heart This email was sent by Amazon Heart, PO Box 59233, San Jose, California 95159-0233

Last summer we were blessed with the presence of two Stellar's Jays that would bug us each evening while we ate, SCREAMING at us to feed them peanuts in the shell, unsalted. They broke into our house numerous times, when the patio door was open and stole peanuts for themselves. Ted (Ted is what we called him) and his pal would also enter the house and steal food off the table, always leaving bird crap! Such rude Stellar's Jays! One day, Ted got a little bit confused and must have thought he was sitting in a tree, or something, but I have photos of Jon & Ted sitting in our living room, Ted was blending into the flowered furniture as if he were outside. It was pretty dang cool. I don't even remember how he got out of the house because the shock of that HUGE bird on my couch was shocking. This year, we haven't seen Ted or his pal, which often makes me wonder what happened to them. In preparation for their summer return, I bad bought them a 10-pound bag of peanuts, which the dogs bust into and eat for themselves - they're on the floor in the kitchen and periodically the opening comes undone with the help of Genevieve - who is just enamored with the bag. She's also taken up sucking on the shells. BACK ON TRACK . . . This summer we've had two huge-ass dragonflies in our house. Now, we've owned parrots, so the Stellar's Jays weren't weird-that was just fricken cool. Now, the dragonflies are freaky! I mean freaky! Their wings make an incredible noise and Mimi goes nuts thinking they're little bugs to eat. (Mimi-the-10-pound-Chihuahua/Silky-Terrier eats all the bugs in our house and is especially fond of sitting on the couch in front of the large living room window, eating bugs. I have lots of nose prints and spit to prove it). So tonight we had our second dragonfly of the season, bonking into the front window. I don't know where it came in from, but the wings were loud and creepy! So Mimi starts going nuts trying to catch it - and succeeds until I scream at her to stop. She lets it go and then proceeds to CATCH IT AGAIN! Cripes. So I have to yell at her again and push her off the couch. I then get the large plastic strainer and one of our fancy Hawaiian tablemats. I get the dragonfly into the strainer and calmly take it to the back deck. I slowly remove the tablemat and it flies off towards the sun. As soon as it gets out, another dragonfly rams up next to it and they fly off into the sun together. So, it appears, that all these birds and dragonflies are partners in crime. I also checked urlLink this cool website to find out more about dragonflies and now I know more than I've ever wanted to know. I found this especially interesting: This is what the bugger looked like in my house tonight! urlLink urlLink Life cycle: A dragonfly undergoes incomplete metamorphosis. The larva hatches from an egg which is laid in water, in plants near water, or even underwater. As this aquatic (living in the water) larva (called a nymph) grows, it molts (loses its old skin) many times. When fully-grown, it emerges from the water, using the claws on its feet to crawl onto a plant. The dragonfly flies away over land. It only returns to the water to reproduce and continue this cycle. The life span ranges from about 6 months to over 7 years (most of it is spent in the nymph stage - the adult lives for only a few weeks). The adult dragonfly has a short life span. It lives just long enough to mature and mate. In the Northern states the first cold of fall kills them off. Only the nymphs remain in their underwater home, carrying on the chain of life, just as they had in the long ago past. For a dragonfly, life and death are simple and direct, and the glittering wings cease beating in the numbing of autumn cold. But through the miracle of Nature, the nymphs will again shed their armor, and take to wing in the sunshine, and we will once again reap the benfit of their voracious appetites.
